instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.ALL_SYS: What is ALL_SYS? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: first i want to make sure. does this need an 85w charger or can this work with a 60w, does the fan spin on startup or is it one that has to get hot first? i do have green light with battery and amber with no battery.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: 60W should work, fan should spin, voltage at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>? <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> present or pulsing?? is this whater damage? Where? Any history?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: no water damage, only history i got was, she was using it, it shut off on its own, she took it to a repair shop in california, and they told her the logic board was shot needed replaced. she lives in kansas so she wanted another opinion when she got back, and here it is on my desk. visually board is hairy but no signs of broken, or corroded parts. i have to wait a while for my voltmeter to come back. co worker took it to another store. ill get voltages shortly and post back

threads.message: if your talking about <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> im not getting a pulse its staying 0. unless i go all the way down on my voltmeter, 200m i get .1 pulse, pretty sure thats not actual voltage

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: There must be a S0 rail that is not pulsing then else <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> would come high. Check all rails for pulsing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: if i missed any rail, please let me know. several rails are doing nothing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Check all rails for shorts to GND, this includes all S3/S4/S0 ones.
